Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Closed-Loop PPMS Enhanced for Multidisciplinary Research and Education at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette
Award.AbstractNarration:
The acquisition of a Physical Property Measurement System provides a multi-user platform for multidisciplinary materials research at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette. The work made possible by this unique and robust instrument enables on-site multidisciplinary research in materials that will be transformative for the region’s research and educational capacity. The instrumentation will be used for fundamental studies; new-materials design; natural and man-made materials characterization; and energy-harvesting materials development. This instrument acquisition enhances several existing research programs, provides additional projects for doctoral students in the new Earth and Energy Science program at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette, and creates the base for summer research sessions for underexposed, underrepresented high school students from the local region. The activities are envisioned to make a marked impact in the development of a technologically well-trained and inclusive workforce.

The acquisition of a DynaCool Physical Property Measurement System provides a multi-user platform for multidisciplinary materials research at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette. The instrument employs closed-loop gas circulation with low-noise non-moving-part technology, with an open architecture that allows for its capabilities to be enhanced with non-standard probes. The platform’s set of adaptable tools is to be used for fundamental studies; new-materials design; natural and man-made materials characterization; energy-storage/harvesting materials development; as well as hypothesis validation. The probes acquired or developed in-house for the cryostat provide measurements of magnetic, elastic, electric, and thermal properties for a wide range of solids. The temperature and magnetic-field dependence of the measured properties are used to uncover and understand lattice dynamics, lattice-electron-moment coupling, or energy interplay within the material studied. Specific activities planned are in the areas of (1) exotic phenomena in magnetism; (2) novel energy-efficient logic and data-storage technologies; (3) origin and decomposition of magnetic signals in rocks; (4) metal additive-manufacturing (AM) qualification and model validation; (5) magnetoresistance tuning in thin films; (6) systematic data collection for geological surveys and new AM-materials databases; (7) magnetoelastic coupling in magnetically-frustrated thermoelectrics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project established a new multidisciplinary research capability for the faculty and students at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette and in the SE Louisiana region. The DynaCool Physical Property Measurement Instrumentation acquired provides a controlled temperature (1.8-400 K) and magnetic field (0-9 T) sample chamber in which the behavior of a multitude of physical properties can be investigated. New materials with special properties are constantly sought after; their properties are tweaked by making changes in their synthesis process; their properties are then studied in the controlled environment provided by the instrument, completing a crucial feedback loop used in successful alloy development. A multitude of materials have been studied during the project period, from magnetotactic bacteria to lunar regolith-derived materials. An example project is that of accurately determining the thermal properties of alloys used in space manufacturing. Together with other properties, these are essential for developing robust property predictors needed for robotic additive manufacturing in space or on extra-terrestrial bases. Measurements of temperature-dependent specific heat of Al100-xSix (x = 3, 6, 9, 12, 20 wt.%) and Fe100-xSix (x = 1, 3, 6, 9, 12 wt.%) (silumin and ferrosilicon, respectively) were conducted by a high school student from an underrepresented group and by an MS student who is now employed at NASA. The property predictors development is continuing with members of the original project team and with new investigators, through newly funded projects and pending proposed work.

The new capability added to the campus of the University of Louisiana at Lafayette is consequential to the region’s education and its research developments. Several new grants were received since the new instrument became part of the available infrastructure. One faculty member was hired partially due to their need of such instrumentation. The many students who worked with the instrument were exposed to modern technology, had an enhanced research experience, and made them more likely to continue on a STEM path. All processes that contribute to a well-trained STEM workforce are known to have an impact on society, immediate or long-term.

The characteristics of the instrument align with the current needs of closed-loop refrigeration and cryogen conservation. The helium used for refrigeration is captured and compressed, and the required liquid cryogen is recirculated with minimal losses.

A highlight of the activities during the project period was an outreach STEAM (Science Technology Engineering Art Mathematics) camp designed for high school students, named “I Belong: Technology and Science for the Future” (IBeTS). The students learned what is involved in scientific discovery and technical innovation. The experience focused on hands-on experimental investigations with magnetic materials (Fe-Ga alloys of different compositions), the technology involved in the DynaCool instrument, data processing and analysis, and the undersatnding/dissemination of their findings. The camp included an art component, where each student built an installation inspired from the works of the artist Takis, using hard and soft magnets. Other stimulating activities were embedded within the program: we had a half-day lecture on Quantum Computing and had scientists from diverse backgrounds talk to the group about what research is and what it entails. The participating students got to know the instrument well and were able to operate it relatively confidently. One student continued to work with other capabilities of the instrument and other materials through a 6-week high-school summer research engagement.
